DESCRIPTION OF THE PLAN

The purpose of the General Development Plan presented here is to pro-
vide information and guidance for the many public and private decisions
which will determine the future form of Baltimore’s metropolitan area.
This plan envisions a more desirable environment for living which this
Region might offer. It is a general suggestion for encouraging sound de-
velopment of our environment. It is long-range, looking ahead twenty to
twenty-five years. The plan recommends a land use pattern and major
public facilities. It is not a zoning map; the power to zone is exercised by
local government.

The plan is the culmination of years of study and research by the
Regional Planning Council, local planning bodies, and other representatives
of governments in the Region. It consists of a set of recommendations,
prepared pursuant to state law, to provide assistance to units of local
government and the state government in meeting the challenge of inevitable
growth. It focuses on problems and opportunities which are common to
several units of government or which affect more than one unit of govern-
ment. ' Its success depends on local action by local units of government,
both as they act individually and as they act through their representatives
on regional and state bodies.

The Regional Planning Council, in cooperation with the planning staffs
of the local and state governments, is undertaking further analyses of the
major elements of the General Development Plan. These studies will be
made public from time to time as they are completed.

The major elements of the plan reflect goals for the future physical
development of the area. The plan provides for well-coordinated develop-
ment of these elements, designed to make the best use of the land. These
elements are briefly described below.

Residential Development

Where and how well people live is the most important aspect of planning.
The residential framework of the plan proposes a variety of residential
development, planned in relation to physical characteristics, open space,

0 5 10

MILES

MILITARY, AIRPORTS



The basic highway network includes both interregional and intraregional .
facilities. Only freeways, expressways, and major urban and rural arterial
roads are shown in the plan. The network has been planned to encourage
development where it would be least costly to provide public services, and
to deter development where it would destroy prize open-space areas or
would be undesirable in other ways.

The principal additions to the existing system acknowledge the major
growth expected toward Columbia and Washington to the southwest, and
toward Wilmington and Philadelphia to the northeast. The new roads
include a new and better U. S. Route 1 extending northeast from the city;
Northwest and Liberty Expressways into the northwest part of the Region;
I-70N westerly in the general location of U. S. Route 40; an improved Route
29 and a continuation of I-95 through Howard County; and the Arundel
Freeway facilitating transportation in the urban portion of Anne Arundel
County and connecting with the Bay Bridge. Other major features include
links from the Beltway into the waterfront and industrial areas of Marley
Neck, Sparrows Point, Back River, and White Marsh; a future second
harbor crossing; and three connector freeways across the southern part of
the Region. In the future, major rural highways could connect the fringes
of the Region from Annapolis to Westminster, and then east across the
northern area to Aberdeen.

The mass transit system will provide vastly improved transportation
service for people travelling within the Region. The 65-mile rail portion
of the transit system consists of a loop surrounding the core of Baltimore,
and radial lines reaching from the inner-city loop outward along six major
development corridors. Subsequent transit extensions are possible to
Aberdeen, Annapolis, Columbia, and Washington when patronage warrants.

The rail rapid-transit system would be supported by a complex of
modern commuter express buses on exclusive rights of way and on the
freeways, and improved feeder bus lines from suburban residential areas
to the rail transit stations.

ANNES good transportation facilities, and convenient shopping areas. The plan Centers for the Region
Tomstee ' proposes four major .categories. of residential development: ’figh densz:ty One of the major advantages of living in or near a metropolitan area
COUNTY areas in the center city and within some town centers; medium density is the wealth of opportunity, and variety available in shopping, cultural

beyond the high density areas and extending along principal transportation
corridors; and wider low density areas. Rural areas identify land recom-
mended to remain predominantly farmland.

These density proposals refer to overall intensity of development within
a sizable area. Many areas might contain not just one form of housing but
a reasonable and practicable variety of housing types.

Not every area shown will actually be developed. The plan leaves ade-
quate room for choice.

Open Space

The open space element of the plan provides many benefits for the
Region’s inhabitants. First, it recognizes the rural values of the Region.
In addition, it preserves features of the natural environment to make the
area more beautiful, protect natural resources, safeguard the water supply,
and provide land for recreation and leisure. One of its major purposes is
to serve as the background for more livable communities which will be
developed within the open space pattern.

There is still much open land because pressures for development have
not reached all of it. However, there is limited open space which is now
permanently reserved for the future. The plan provides a guide for the
public action which is needed to safeguard this natural heritage.

The plan defines three categories of open space. One is the primary
system which requires either acquisition or some form of public protection
of land which is subject to early development pressures, or which protects
public water supply watersheds, or contains unique natural features. The
primary system provides an interconnected series of reserves and recreation
areas which link together major existing recreation areas and open spaces,
areas of exceptional natural beauty, scenic and historic sites, and flood
plains. It generally follows the major stream and river valleys. Other parts
of the primary system include other water bodies, smaller scenic valleys and
historic sites, available open space around the headwaters of other rivers,
and scattered but significant public recreation sites along the bay.

activities, educational facilities, and numerous other aspects of daily urban
living.

The plan shows a development pattern which can improve these oppor-
tunities and make them more available to more people.

A strong central core for the Region is explicit in the plan — from the
strengthened highway network and the rail mass-transit system to the
revitalized high-density residential districts in the central area. These

. features work to reinforce the core as a thriving financial, business, resi-
dential, and cultural center supporting the economy of the Region, and
serving as a vital center of activity around the clock.

In addition to a strong downtown, a number of town centers are proposed
to serve as secondary concentrations of business and other activity. These
centers will offer a variety of urban opportunities including retail, com-
mercial services, and entertainment facilities. They can include govern-
ment, educational, institutional, and residential complexes. Many, like
the centers .of Towson and Annapolis, exist today. They are all located
amid large existing and future communities and are closely coordinated
with the transportation system, both highway and transit.

As the growth of the area continues, new carefully planned centers
should be created in presently undeveloped areas to serve these new com-
munities.

Industrial Land

Good industrial land is essential for the economic growth of any populous
region. Thousands of additional acres of land must be reserved for indus-
trial expansion in coming decades. At the present time, the largest in-
dustrial establishments are located around the Patapsco waterfront. Smaller
industrial developments are located throughout the Region.

Good transportation, water and sewer facilities, and other services are
necessary for industry. Areas proposed for industrial use in the plan are
along major highway and rail networks, at critical transportation intersec-

_ SECONDARY : FREEWAY , s A secondary system defines additional desirable natural areas not tions, and around the port. Major expansion is planned ultil.nately between
. = MAJOR URBAN, RURAL HIGHWAY threatened now, but eventually necessary to supplement the primary system. I-95 and the bay in the northeast corridor, around Back River, in Marley

oeooeeeee RAIL RAPID MHSH' ; : The third system shows conservation areas, where development should be NCCk’ alon'g I-83 north of ?he Beltway, around Friendship Airport, and

- CONSERVATION essscscee POSSIBLE TRANSIT EXTENSION sparse and restricted for the protection of natural resources or amenities. in the corridor between Baltimore and Washington near the proposed I-95



Most of the secondary system, and practically all of the conservation areas,
would remain in private ownership.

Transportation

The transportation network provides mobility for the citizens and visitors
of the Region. It determines how quickly and conveniently people can
travel within the Region. It guides growth by providing access to land
areas, and it represents the largest single public capital investment in the
Region. The two major features in the system are highways and mass
transit, both bus and rail.

and Baltimore-Washington Parkway.

Much of the success of the General Development Plan depends on the
people who live in the Region. Through their day-to-day decisions of where
to shop, where to build an apartment development, how to get to work,
where to build an industrial park, what to do on the weekend, the people
who live here, work here, invest here, and shop here will provide the
demand for which the public agencies will make their decisions.

This plan can offer a long-range guide to aid the people who must make

these decisions. G33q d
